text: The sun hangs high above, the town gates half open. The wind carries the scent of charcoal and spices.
“See? I told you the sun would be good today.”
Alicia narrows her eyes slightly, gazing down the street.
“Good enough to blind someone.”
I raise a hand to shield my eyes. The stone beneath our feet radiates heat.

Vendors at the gate pour fruit into wooden barrels. A gust of wind sends the scent of ripe sweetness and warm air toward us. Children run past chasing paper pinwheels, their laughter bright and clear.
“So this is the town market.”
Her gaze travels along the busy street, curious and assessing. “It’s livelier than I expected.”
“You really haven’t been here before?”
“No. First time.”
She smiles faintly. “Patrol guards spend more time outside the walls than inside.”
“Then we’d better make it worth the trip.”
“If I hadn’t brought you along, you’d still be out there getting your boots chewed off by a monster.”
She huffs softly—but she’s smiling.
We cross the central square. Sunlight glints off the white stone statue, the clocktower’s shadow stretching long. Voices, clattering pots, and hoofbeats blend into a vivid tapestry of life.
“At least we can breathe in town.”
She stretches lightly, her tone relaxed. “But don’t relax too much. If monsters are roaming, we may need to check the western line later.”
“Can’t we rest first?”
“We can.”
She arches a brow. “Though I doubt monsters will politely wait for us to feel ready.”
I open my mouth to argue, but her turning smile cuts me off—shallow, yet genuine.
The crowd thins slightly as the afternoon settles. Just then, a vendor’s call rings out ahead.
Alicia glances at me, a hint of curiosity in her eyes. “Want to take a look?”

We follow the voice to a stall lined with small wares: leather sheaths, whetstones, simple bracers, and several short wooden practice swords. Most eye-catching is a freshly polished short blade—compact, but bright enough to shimmer.
“How much for this one?”
The vendor sizes me up and smiles warmly. “Not much. Forged by the town smith. I’ll give you a fair price—good for self-defense.”
Alicia glances at the blade. “Don’t pick something flashy. What matters is how it feels in your hand.”
I wrap my fingers around the hilt. The wood grain and leather binding settle naturally against my palm. The sunlight glints along the edge, and for a moment, even my lingering unease feels steadier.
“I’ll take it.”
I pay and fasten the small sword and simple sheath at my side. It’s not heavy—but each step feels firmer than before.
